reuters.unknown: RM f reute u f BC JAPAN FARM REFORM A K

text.title: JAPAN FARM REFORM A KEY TO TRIMMING TRADE SURPLUS
text.author: By Linda Sieg Reuters
text.body: Basic reform Japan s protected farm sector key to shifting economy away export to domestic led growth vital step if to trim trade surplus securities analysts farm sector protected by import tariffs quotas propped up by subsidies price supports sheltered by tax system ample room change they In economic terms reform be plus Christopher Chew brokerage firm James Capel Co ultimate cost existing system food prices twice those Europe two to three times those U S analysts Spending on food accounts one quarter average household s budget roughly pct gross national product GNP according to study by Chew Reducing these prices could increase household spending power by five pct his study money could be spent on products more direct impact boosting domestic growth added There s lot slack U S Government official Tokyo All money could be spent on something else Direct central government subsidies to farm sector amount to some five billion dlrs per year Independent estimates put total subsidies all sources as high as billion analysts much money wasted Changing tax laws to encourage city residents who only farm on weekends to put their land up sale residential development also give boost to domestic spending economists Housing construction key strategic variable expansion domestic demand wrote Chihiro Nakajima professor at Kyoto Gakuen University Japanese business groups calling staged farm reform to shift some burden trade friction economic restructuring away manufacturing sector onto farm sector Employers groups also want change If you really want to expand domestic demand way to do to raise wages recklessly but to reduce commodity prices Bumpei Otsuki President Japan Federation Employers Associations told recent press conference External pressures rising as U S Europe seek removal tariffs quotas to help reduce their trade deficits Japan But vested Japanese interests opposed to change remain well entrenched dimming prospects quick reform analysts Although full time farm population falling there signs LDP paying more attention to urban constituencies ruling party remains heavily dependent on farm votes rural areas One rural vote worth several city votes due to pattern constituency borders LDP already political trouble over tax reform plan does want to raise another sticky issue so soon analysts Consumer groups politically weak tend to accept traditional view higher prices small fee to pay national food security they Powerful agricultural cooperatives fiercely opposed to import liberalisation but more flexible reforms aimed at stepping up productivity they Reform when comes be response to specific pressure rather than all embracing program Chew

text.title: SRI LANKA AND IMF AGREE ON ECONOMIC REFORMS
text.author: By Marilyn Odchimar Reuters
text.body: Sri Lanka International Monetary Fund IMF reached agreement on broad outline economic reforms but tough negotiations likely before IMF approves up to dlrs loans senior finance ministry official told Reuters He government IMF week agreed on package to reduce balance payments deficit improve management public enterprises reform tariffs develop non traditional exports privatise public firms IMF World Bank team visit Colombo next month to start negotiations on details three year economic reform programme There broad agreement on content policy package structural reform official But areas where reform take place there be tough neotiations on how much you do what order should take place he added Sri Lanka seeking total dlrs structural adjustment loans to support balance payments compensatory financing facility to offset losses commodity exports Sri Lanka needs IMF World Bank approval two facilities to clear way negotiations on requests aid loans donor countries These include expected pledge dlrs industrialised countries dlrs loans World Bank Asian Development Bank Finance Minister Ronnie De Mel interview published today by Daily News there likelihood Sri Lanka obtaining all aid despite intense lobbying by pro Tamil human rights groups abroad He although friendly countries were still prepared to assist Sri Lanka concessional aid Colombo to surmount many problems detailed negotiations due May June August before these loans finalised In these matters there s many slip between cup lip as other governments learned to their cost De Mel

happy we coming but they going to give us anything Lyng U S Officials do expect any Japanese concessions during Lyng s two week visit here Any farm trade concessions be unveiled later month they If lifting longstanding ban on foreign purchases private U S Rice trader visited Tokyo week requesting Japan buy tonnes rice industrial uses such as making sake Japan rejected overture saying Tokyo example California company transports live U S Cattle to Japan by air slaughter to circumvent beef quota cost transport higher than value animal he U S Officials Japan Livestock Industry Promotion press Japan to eliminate import quotas on fresh oranges orange juice by April Some U S Officials believe Japan may eventually be willing to scrap quota on fresh oranges because liberalized trade necessarily damage Japanese mandarin orange industry quota on juice may be harder to eliminate because imports might replace domestic produced juice U S Japanese officials Lyng resurrected past U S Proposal Japan buy surplus U S Foodgrains donation to developing countries but some U S Officials skeptical action be taken Lyng also urge Japan to put domestic farm policies including rice on negotiating table during GATT talks Geneva He Japan must eliminate import quotas on certain minor food products or face possible U S Reprisals

text.title: REAGAN TO ANNOUNCE DECISION ON JAPAN SANCTIONS
text.author: By Robert Trautman Reuters
text.body: President Reagan today to announce decision on tough new tariffs on Japanese exports to retaliate what he calls Japan s failure to end unfair practices semiconductor trade pct tariffs to be imposed on dlrs Japanese goods recommended curbs by special panel experts headed by U S Trade Representative s Office Reagan announced March he impose tariffs on certain goods taken list ranged computors television sets to power tools photographic film panel week winnowed through list some products sent their recommendations yesterday to Santa Barbara where Reagan vacationing his March annoucement Reagan I am committed to full enforcement our trade agreements designed to provide American industry free fair trade opportunities He added tariffs be lifted once Japan honored pact signed year to end dumping semiconductors world markets opened home market to U S products U S officials Japan done nothing since March announcement to alter Reagan s plan to invoke sanctions White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater yesterday we do want trade war but we feel kind action requires meaningful action Reagan s move follows steadily rising U S trade deicits year s hitting record billion one third deficit trade Japan Congress weighing trade bill to force president to retaliate certain cases unfair trade practices He opposed legislation saying prevent negotiated solutions to trade disputes any case existing law adqeuate to end unfair trade practices Trade experts say his tough action against Japanese as much to penalize Japanese as to show Congress he did need any new trade legislation Japanese complained they been honoring semiconductor pact but take time before results showed up U S officials however their monitoring Japanese semiconductor shipments to East Asian countries Western Europe showed no letup dumping Japanese home markets remained shut to American exports Japan if Reagan imposed tariffs file complaint General Agreement on Tariff Trade GATT hoped GATT find U S retaliation violated regulations global trading group approve compensation or Japanese retaliation U S officials they did think Japan retaliate because too much to lose any trade war United States

text.title: ARGENTINA SEES QUICK COMPLETION OF DEBT DEAL
text.author: By Alan Wheatley Reuters
text.body: Argentina s controversial new financing package should be completed quickly thanks to wide range innovative options deal Jorge Gonzalez undersecretary external debt economics ministry deal offers banks lucrative fee if they sign early exit bond provision allowing banks to sell as much as five dlrs their existing loans Gonzalez also disclosed banks choice lending up to one dlrs form bearer bond We expect to complete package very quickly he telephone interview By providing their share billion dlrs new money being raised Argentina via easily tradable bearer bond instead participation syndicated loan smaller banks could avoid time consuming legal paperwork bonds currently dubbed alternative participation instruments carry same terms as syndicated loan year term five years grace interest rate margin pct over Eurodollar rates Gonzalez idea exit bond creditor bank may exchange up to five dlrs existing debt new tradeable bond bears below market interest rates return accepting lower yield amount debt converted be subtracted bank s exposure purposes calculating contribution to future new loans Gonzalez difficult to say how many banks take up exit bonds because no such instrument been offered before On paper however Argentina s lending syndicate could shrink dramatically because over country s creditors exposure less than five dlrs Details exit bonds still being finalized Gonzalez added Argentina pressed hard streamlining lending process because bitter memories package agreed Citibank led steering committee December but signed until August Gonzalez praised committee cooperation latest negotiations resulting deal announced by banks on Wednesday should put Argentina on road to meeting economic goals We believe package help Argentine to continue on track elected to follow stable growth equilibrium external accounts he Asked what role Reagan Administration played final stages talks Gonzalez lent practical support He did elaborate but bankers U S pressed agreement after Economics Minister Juan Sourrouille threatened at week s spring meeting Washington International Monetary Fund to break off talks unless banks stopped blocking deal specter Argentina emulating Brazil suspending interest payments haunted policymakers bankers alike who long feared emergence debtors cartel That feeling among people on committee one banker As result bankers agreed to give Argentina same interest rate margin as Mexico pct on rescheduling billion dlrs debt even though they knew raise ire Philippines Venezuela paid pct on recent rescheduling packages Asked angry reaction Manila government promptly Wednesday demand spread pct Gonzalez matter between Philippines banks

text.author: By Alan Wheatley Reuters

compromise Ongpin angry because banks granted Argentina interest rate spread pct same as Mexico won just weeks after telling Philippines must accept pct because Mexican margin could never be repeated text.title: JAPANESE TARIFFS SEEN AS WORLDWIDE WARNING
text.author: By Robert Trautman Reuters
text.body: The tough trade sanctions President Reagan imposed on Japanese exports only shot across Japan s bow but also sign Reagan attack unfair trade practices worldwide U S officials But Robert Crandall trade specialist at Brookings Institution think tank a shot across their bow can often result shot our stern He left United States open to retaliation U S officials pct tariffs Reagan ordered on dlrs worth Japanese goods also show Congress tough pro trade stand can be taken under existing laws no new protectionist legislation needed past year tough trade action been taken against European Community over corn sorghum Taiwan over beer wine South Korea over counterfeiting copyrights patents trademarkets Japan on tobacco White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters tariffs up five pct should be seen as serious signal to other nations on need fair trade practices Reagan he imposed sanctions on certain computers television sets some hand tools because Japan did honor agreement to end dumping semiconductors world markets at less than cost to open markets to U S products tariffs were placed on items were available other sources so there be little effect on American consumer Fitzwater Reagan come under heavy pressure to take tougher action especially against Japan to end global unfair trade practices reverse growing U S trade deficit alternative if he did Congress U S trade gap year record billion dlrs continues to rise Japan accounting one third America s overall deficit But there other two way deficits Canada West Germany Taiwan South Korea Reagan officials president ready to fight them all Reagan announcing sanctions today I regret these actions necessary but health vitality U S semiconductor industry essential to American competitiveness world markets We cannot allow to be jeopardized by unfair trading practices Reagan added statement his California vacation home at Santa Barbara He tariffs remain force until Japan abided by agreement U S officials say action today show Congress to write trade bill he does like he already tools needed to fight unfair trade White House aide tariff action it wasn t done to appease Congress but because there unfair trade practice aide added however on another plane example how administration uses trade law to fight unfair practices necessary to make major overall our trade laws But analyst Crandall tariff action best interests United States negotiations should been pursued to resolve issue It s very dangerous to go down retaliatory route he because leads to more retaliation restrictions trade Crandall the administration doing political impact across country therefore impact on Congress He I don t think makes lot sense But other analysts made little difference whether tariffs were aimed at U S trading partners or Congress main point trading partners were on notice retaliation weapon Reagan ready to use Spokesman Fitzwater we don t want trade war but imposition sanctions showed United States act when evidence trade pacts were being violated Crandall the administration doing political impact across country therefore impact on Congress He I don t think makes lot sense But other analysts made little difference whether tariffs were aimed at U S trading partners or Congress main point trading partners were on notice retaliation weapon Reagan ready to use Spokesman Fitzwater we don t want trade war but imposition sanctions showed United States act when evidence trade pacts were being violated

reuters.unknown: RM f reute u f BC WORLD BANK SUGGESTS M

text.title: WORLD BANK SUGGESTS MORE OPEN ECONOMY FOR INDIA
text.author: By Ajoy Sen Reuters
text.body: The World Bank suggested India should move to more open economy by gradually removing most government controls on industry adopting liberal external trade policy reduced levels protection confidential executive summary draft Bank report on Indian economy made available to Reuters suggests liberalisation as part package reforms to boost exports Indian goods by making them more competitive summary These reforms result domestic prices much more line world prices than true today greater degree import competition export rivalry than nation ever seen summary foreign trade must play key role India s transition towards more dynamic economy Liberal imports capital goods help modernise economy expose Indian producers to foreign competition Larger exports provide foreign exchange imports The main guideline unambiguously to abandon present principle unlimited protection all indigenously available products to recognise role actual or potential competition imports as source discipline on prices costs public private sector domestic manufacturers summary Indian official told Reuters government discussing report Bank final report some changes likely to be ready by May but he declined to give further details Bank industrialised nations discuss Bank s final report at meeting Paris on June to discuss aid India year starting June summary India s gross domestic product gdp grew at average five pct Indian fiscal years ended March investment being sustained at nearly pct gdp Almost pct investment being financed by national savings mainly private sector India s trade deficit officially to narrowed to billion dlrs ended March record billion dlrs current account deficit fell to billion dlrs billion But summary improvement largely due to lower prices crude oil petroleum products fertilisers make up bulk India s import bill India able to save billion dlrs foreign exchange due to lower prices those products summary Bank s summary there little room complacency balance payments position despite lower trade deficit Indian foreign exchange reserves fell by dlrs Real export growth need to average at least pct year value terms coming years to maintain viable balance payments summary did explicitly suggest rupee should be devalued India might to reaffirm commitment to exporting while undertaking some dramatic changes general incentives involve some political costs An example such policy be adoption exchange rate regime maintained exporters profitability summary such approach been successful countries such as South Korea Colombia Turkey maintain competitiveness Indian exports simultaneously reduce import pressures Earlier year Indian government denied World Bank asked to devalue Indian rupee to boost exports

text.body: Falconbridge Ltd expected results rest to improve earlier reported first quarter operating loss dlrs Chief executive William James told reporters after annual meeting I hope loss year certainly wouldn t be high as loss first quarter other words we going to make money here on Falconbridge year made first quarter operating loss dlrs full year operating loss dlrs James currency losses tied to stronger Canadian dollar resulted eight dlrs first quarter operating loss Falconbridge records cash accounts receivable U S dollars Canadian dollar equivalent decreasing as U S dollar falls He first quarter loss also stemmed weaker nickel ferronickel prices lower production at company s Sudbury Ontario nickel operations at some Kidd Creek operations Falconbridge anticipates higher production through rest year higher average prices year precious metals James added without elaborating Falconbridge no immediate plans further divestments James reply to reporters inquiries company sold several mining subsidiaries year to help pay down debt January acquisition Kidd Creek Mines Ltd Canada Development Corp CDC TO He Falconbridge s debt now totaled one billion dlrs down billion dlrs at time Kidd Creek buy James he could assess impact Amoco Corp AN s proposed acquisition Dome Petroleum Ltd DMP Dome s pct owned Dome Mines Ltd DM owns pct Falconbridge Asked by reporters if Falconbridge preferred competing Dome bidder Calgary Alberta based TransCanada PipeLines Ltd to Chicago based Amoco James replied It makes no difference to me whoever takes over fine by us He told shareholders Falconbridges planned capital expenditures year decline to dlrs dlrs year

text.title: TRANSCANADA TRP DENIES REPORTS OF NEW BID
text.body: TransCanada PipeLines Ltd denied reports raised offer Dome Petroleum Ltd DMP to billion Canadian dlrs billion report on Canadian Broadcasting Corp CBC late night TransCanada s new bid rejected by Dome accepted billion dlr bid Amoco Corp AN We still want to acquire Dome s assets prepared to negotiate However we presented new proposal to company since April Dome refused to negotiate TransCanada since date TransCanada president Gerald Maier TransCanada proposal consists two parts billion dlrs cash securities one billion dlrs payments to creditors based on future profits week TransCanada valued first part offer at billion dlrs but spokesman today company increased estimated value part to billion dlrs after recent gain Dome s stock Dome halted today on Toronto Stock Exchange pending clarification TransCanada s offer traded at dlrs per share Two weeks ago before TransCanada s offer Dome traded at dlrs per share
